Name: Radar
Description: This class is the top level class that contains other radar classes, separated by sub-discipline.

Name: Groundbased_Radar
Description: This class contains attributes that describe metadata pertinent to radar observations / data from Arecibo, Goldstone, and similar installations.

Name: observation_purpose
Description: Type of radar experiment being performed. Simpler experiments can have higher signal-to-noise or simpler hardware configurations, while more complicated experiments provide more information. ‘Range’ and ‘Total Power’ are mostly historical.

Name: Doppler
Description: Received signal is analyzed as a function of Doppler shift with separation by range.

Name: Range
Description: Transmitted signal is modulated in order to resolve and/or local the target in range, but the entire received signal is analyzed without separation by Doppler shift.

Name: Range-Doppler
Description: Transmitted signal is modulated in order to resolve and/or locate the target in range. Received signal is analyzed as a function of Doppler shift in each range bin.

Name: Total Power
Description: Only the total echo power is measured, with no separation in range or Doppler shift.

Name: Transmitter_Properties
Description: Transmitter properties

Name: range_resolution
Description: range resolution of images

Name: tx_power
Description: transmitter power input to antenna

Name: Modulation
Description: Modulation

Name: power_modulation
Description: On/off modulation (pulsing) of the transmitted power with time to provide range resolution, allow reception of echo in gaps, or cooling of the transmitter. Power modulation other than pulsing should be included in waveform modulation.

Name: CW
Description: Continuous Wave. Transmitter operates continuously while in operation.

Name: Pulsed
Description: The transmitter operates for a series of short intervals, typically microseconds or milliseconds, while in operation.

Name: waveform_modulation
Description: Additional modulation of the amplitude, phase or frequency of the transmitted signal, usually to provide range resolution. Referred to as “pulse compression” in some literature.

Name: Barker BPSK
Description: A Barker Binary Phase Shift code is applied, usually to a pulse, to improve range resolution.

Name: Linear Chirp
Description: A repeating sawtooth linear frequency ramp is applied to the transmitted signal in order to resolve the target in range.

Name: Non-repeating BPSK
Description: A non-repeating pseudo-random code is applied to the transmitted signal using Binary Phase-Shift Keying in order to resolve the target in range.

Name: Other
Description: A modulation beyond a pulse and other than described above is applied to the signal.

Name: Other BPSK
Description: A code other than those described above is applied to the transmitted signal using Binary Phase-Shift Keying.

Name: Other Chirp
Description: A frequency ramp other than described above is applied to the transmitted signal.

Name: Repeating LFSR BPSK
Description: A maximal-length Linear Feedback Shift Register code is applied to the transmitted signal using Binary Phase-Shift Keying, in order to resolve the target in range.

Name: Uncoded
Description: No additional modulation beyond a pulse (if present) is applied to the signal in order to encode range information.

Name: Quality
Description: Quality

Name: matched_snr
Description: total matched-filter signal-to-noise ratio in one run

Name: pixel_number
Description: number of pixels in an image with measurable signal

Name: Target_Properties
Description: Target Properties

Name: roundtrip_lighttime
Description: round trip lighttime to target at time of observation

Name: range_depth
Description: number of pixels in an image with measurable signal
